# Trust Attitudes in the Use of Artificial Intelligence
- public:: true
	- KPMG & Univ. of Melbourne
		- (48 000 workers across 47 countries) - Nov 2024 - Jan 2025
		- ![trust-attitudes-and-use-of-ai-global-report.pdf](../assets/trust-attitudes-and-use-of-ai-global-report_1746178190862_0.pdf)
	- Some key findings
		- 50 % present AI-generated content as their own
		- 67 % intentionally use AI at work
		- 69 % say their organization uses AI
		- 54 % report increased efficiency, quality, and innovation
		- 43 % report increased revenue-generating activity
		- 28 % report increased workload stress and pressure
			- **Organizational readiness**
				- 60 % have an AI strategy in place
				- 54 % have responsible‐use policies
			- **Tool sources & skills gap**
				- 70 % use publicly available free AI tools (non-enterprise-grade)
				- 42 % feel they have the skills/knowledge to use AI appropriately
				- 28 % have formal or informal AI training
				- 52 % feel they can use AI tools effectively
			- **Risk behaviors**
				- ≈ 60 % (“three in five”) have seen colleagues misuse AI tools
				- ≈ 66 % (“two in three”) rely on AI outputs without evaluation
				- over 50 % have made mistakes in their work due to AI
	- **Implications & leadership gaps**
		- Trust gap exists more between employees and leaders than with AI itself
		- Leadership deficits in providing tools, policies, training, guidelines, and clear communication
	- **Shifting skill requirements**
		- From individual productivity “co-pilot” tools to design and integration of agentic systems
		- Urgent need for training on building, provisioning, and managing AI agent teams
- # Earlier studies
	- 75 % of knowledge workers using AI
	- 78 % of those bring their own tools to work without informing colleagues or managers (Microsoft: “BYO AI”)
	- 48 % of workers uncomfortable telling managers they use AI for common tasks (Earlier Slack)

## Current Landscape (2025)

- Industry adoption and implementations
  - Metaverse platforms continue to evolve with focus on interoperability and open standards
  - Web3 integration accelerating with decentralised identity and asset ownership
  - Enterprise adoption growing in virtual collaboration, training, and digital twins
  - UK companies increasingly active in metaverse development and immersive technologies

- Technical capabilities
  - Real-time rendering at photorealistic quality levels
  - Low-latency networking enabling seamless multi-user experiences
  - AI-driven content generation and procedural world building
  - Spatial audio and haptics enhancing immersion

- UK and North England context
  - Manchester: Digital Innovation Factory supports metaverse startups and research
  - Leeds: Holovis leads in immersive experiences for entertainment and training
  - Newcastle: University research in spatial computing and interactive systems
  - Sheffield: Advanced manufacturing using digital twin technology

- Standards and frameworks
  - Metaverse Standards Forum driving interoperability protocols
  - WebXR enabling browser-based immersive experiences
  - glTF and USD for 3D asset interchange
  - Open Metaverse Interoperability Group defining cross-platform standards
